context: <a0_0><b5_0>Rapid environmental changes<b5_0/><a0_0/> typically cause mass extinctions. <a1_0><b6_0>More than 99 percent<b6_0/><a1_0/> of all species, amounting to <a2_0><b7_0>over five billion<b7_0/> species<a2_0/>, that ever lived on Earth are estimated to be extinct. Estimates on the number of <a3_0>Earth's current species range from <b8_0>10 million to 14 million<b8_0/>,<a3_0/> of which about 1.2 million have been documented and over 86 percent have not yet been described. The total amount of related DNA base pairs on Earth is estimated at 5.0 x 1037, and weighs <a4_0><b9_0>50 billion tonnes<b9_0/><a4_0/>. In comparison, the total mass of the biosphere has been estimated to be as much as 4 TtC (trillion tons of carbon).
